description: From Middle English amorous, amerous (14th century), from Old French amoros, amoreus, from Vulgar Latin *amōrōsus, from Latin amor (“love”), related to amāre (“to love”). Compare French amoureux (“in love”).

adjectives.description: amorous (comparative more amorous, superlative most amorous)

entries.meaning: Inclined or having a propensity to love, or to sexual enjoyment.
examples: We were both feeling amorous so the inevitable happened.
She kept making these amorous suggestions.

entries.meaning: Of or relating to, or produced by, love.
examples: She read me an amorous poem.

entries.meaning: (dated) Affected with love; in love; enamored.
examples: He had been amorous of her since schooldays.
